title-group.article-title: Applying Max-and-Smooth to the UKCP data

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: This document describes the implementation of the Max-and-Smooth algorithm for fast approximate Bayesian inference in spatial extreme value analysis of climate projections provided by the UKCP. The algorithm is specifically applied to Generalized Extreme Value (GEV) distributions and is implemented in C++ with R interfaces using Rcpp and RcppEigen.

sec.title: Package Overview
sec.p: The maxandsmooth R package provides tools for fast approximate Bayesian inference for spatial GEV models. The core of the package is implemented in C++ for efficiency, with R wrappers for ease of use.
Key features of the package include:

list-item.p: Implementation of the Max-and-Smooth algorithm for GEV distributions
Efficient C++ code using Eigen for linear algebra operations
Spatial modeling of GEV parameters using Intrinsic Conditional Autoregressive (ICAR) priors
R interface for easy integration into existing extreme value analysis workflows

sec.title: Algorithm Description
sec.p: The Max-and-Smooth algorithm, as applied to spatial GEV models, consists of two main steps:

list-item.p: Max Step: Maximum likelihood estimation of GEV parameters at each spatial location
Smooth Step: Spatial smoothing of the maximum likelihood estimates using a latent Gaussian field

sec.p: The algorithm treats the ML estimates as sufficient statistics for a latent Gaussian field, providing a fast approximation to full Bayesian inference for spatial extreme value models.

sec.title: Code Structure
sec.p: The package is organized into several key files:

list-item.p: src/max.cpp: Implements the Max step (maximum likelihood estimation for GEV)
src/smooth.cpp: Implements the Smooth step (latent Gaussian field smoothing)
src/maxandsmooth.cpp: Ties together the Max and Smooth steps
src/gev.cpp: Implements GEV-specific functions for likelihood and gradient calculations

sec.title: Max Step
sec.p: The Max step involves computing location-wise maximum likelihood estimates (MLEs) for the GEV model parameters. This step is performed independently for each location, treating the data as if it were independent across locations.

sec.title: Data Structure
sec.p: The input data Y, calculated from the UKCP, is structured as a matrix, where:

list-item.p: Rows represent observations of hourly maximum rainfall in yearly blocks
Columns represent different spatial locations over Great Britain.

sec.title: Maximum Likelihood Estimation
sec.p: For each location (column in Y), we compute the MLEs for the three GEV parameters: location (\mu)(μ), scale (\sigma)(σ), and shape (\xi)(ξ). The log-likelihood function for the GEV distribution at a single location is:
where nn is the number of observations at the location.
The MLEs are obtained by maximizing this likelihood function with respect to the parameters:
where Y_iYi is the data for location ii.

sec.title: Link Functions
sec.p: Instead of directly maximizing the likelihood with the original parameters, we transform the parameters using a link function

sec.title: Implementation
sec.p: The maximization is performed using numerical optimization techniques. In our C++ implementation, we use the following approach:

list-item.p: Parameters are transformed with a link function
The negative log-likelihood and its gradient are computed on the unconstrained scale
A numerical optimizer is used to find the MLEs as well as the Hessians at each location’s optimum.

sec.p: The output of this step includes:

list-item.p: A vector of parameter estimates, \hat\etaη̂, ordered such that each station’s location parameter appears first, followed by scale parameters, then shape parameters:
where nn is the number of stations.

A precision matrix, Q_{\eta y}Qηy, constructed from the negative Hessians of the log-likelihood at the MLE estimates. Due to the parameter ordering in \hat\etaη̂, Q_{\eta y}Qηy can be described as a 3×3 block matrix:

where each block Q_{ij}Qij is an n \times nn×n diagonal matrix. The diagonal elements of Q_{ii}Qii correspond to the negative second derivatives of the log-likelihood with respect to the ii-th parameter at each station. The off-diagonal blocks Q_{ij}Qij (where i \neq ji≠j) contain the negative mixed partial derivatives of the log-likelihood with respect to the ii-th and jj-th parameters.
For example, the elements of Q_{\psi\psi}Qψψ are the conditional precisions of the location parameters:
and the elements of Q_{\mu\xi}Qμξ are the conditional dependencies between the location and shape parameters:

sec.p: This structure reflects the independence assumption between stations in the Max step, while capturing the parameter dependencies within each station. The outputs, \hat \etaη̂ and Q_{\eta y}Qηy, serve as inputs into the Smooth step.

sec.title: Smooth Step
sec.p: The Smooth step involves Bayesian inference on a latent Gaussian field, using the maximum likelihood estimates from the Max step as data.

sec.title: Model Structure
sec.p: Let \etaη be the latent field of parameters, and \hat{\eta}η̂ be the maximum likelihood estimates from the Max step. The model is structured as follows:

list-item.p: Data level: \hat{\eta} | \eta \sim N(\eta, Q_{\eta y}^{-1})η̂|η∼N(η,Qηy−1)
Latent level: \eta | \tau_\eta \sim N(0, Q_\eta^{-1})η|τη∼N(0,Qη−1)
Hyperparameter level: \tau_\eta \sim \pi(\tau_\eta)τη∼π(τη)

sec.p: where Q_{\eta y}Qηy is the precision matrix from the Max step, and Q_\etaQη is the precision matrix of the latent field, parameterized by hyperparameters \tau_\etaτη.

sec.title: Data Level
sec.p: The data level models the relationship between the observed maximum likelihood estimates \hat{\eta}η̂ and the true latent field \etaη:

Here, Q_{\eta y}Qηy is the precision matrix obtained from the Max step, representing the uncertainty in the MLE estimates. This can be thought of as using the outputs of the Max step as sufficient statistics for the observed data.

sec.title: Latent Level
sec.p: The latent level models the spatial structure of the parameter field: \eta | \tau_\eta \sim N(0, Q_\eta^{-1}) η|τη∼N(0,Qη−1)

Here, Q_\etaQη is a block diagonal precision matrix that encodes the spatial dependence structure of the latent field. The block diagonal structure reflects the assumption of independence between different parameters, while allowing for spatial correlation within each parameter field. The precision matrix Q_\etaQη is constructed as follows:
where
and \tau_\eta = \left(\tau_\psi, \tau_\tau, \tau_\phi\right)^Tτη=(τψ,ττ,τϕ)T are the hyperparameters controlling the strength of spatial dependence for each parameter.

sec.title: Hyperparameter Level
sec.p: The hyperparameters \tau_\etaτη are assigned prior distributions.

sec.title: MCMC Sampling
sec.p: The Smooth step uses Metropolis-Hastings MCMC to sample from this posterior. The algorithm alternates between:

list-item.p: Proposing new hyperparameters \tau_\eta^*τη*
Accepting or rejecting the proposal based on the Metropolis-Hastings ratio
Sampling a new latent field \eta^*η* conditional on \tau_\eta^*τη*

sec.title: Caltulating the Metropolis-Hastings Ratio
sec.p: The marginal posterior density of \tau_\etaτη given \hat \etaη̂ is \pi(\tau_\eta\vert\hat\eta) \propto \pi(\tau_\eta)\pi(\hat\eta\vert\tau_\eta)π(τη|η̂)∝π(τη)π(η̂|τη) and it can be represented as

using the fact that \pi(\hat\eta \vert \tau_\eta)\pi(\eta\vert\hat\eta, \tau_\eta) = \pi(\hat\eta\vert\eta,\tau_\eta)\pi(\eta\vert\tau_\eta)π(η̂|τη)π(η|η̂,τη)=π(η̂|η,τη)π(η|τη). The densities on the right hand contain \etaη, but since the density is independent of \etaη we can choose any value for \etaη (for example 0) when calculating the marginal posterior of \tau_\etaτη. In the following, we will show the densities when \eta = 0η=0
This is a normal distribution:
Up to a proportionality constant, this evaluates to
Since we can choose \eta = 0η=0, we get
A value that is completely independent of \etaη and \tau_etaτeta. This means we can pre-compute it only once and store the values.
Up to a proportionality constant, this evaluates to
Choosing \eta = 0η=0, this simplifies to
We can precompute the determinant of Q_\text{prior}Qprior and perform these calculations efficiently
where

alternatives.tex-math: Q_{\text{post}} = Q_{\eta y} + Q_\eta \qquad \text{and} \qquad \mu_{\text{post}} = Q_{\text{post}}^{-1}\hat b_{\eta y}.

sec.p: Up to a proportionality constant, this becomes
Choosing \eta = 0η=0, we get
but

alternatives.tex-math: \mu_\text{post}^TQ_\text{post}\mu_\text{post} = (Q_\text{post}^{-1}\hat b_{\eta y})^T Q_\text{post}(Q_\text{post}^{-1}\hat b_{\eta y}) = \hat b_{\eta y}^TQ_\text{post}^{-1}\hat b_{\eta y}

sec.p: Writing this up using the Cholesky factor, L_\text{post}Lpost of Q_\text{post}Qpost, we get

alternatives.tex-math: \hat b_{\eta y}^TQ_\text{post}^{-1}\hat b_{\eta y} = \hat b_{\eta y}^T(L_\text{post} L_\text{post}^T)^{-1}\hat b_{\eta y} = \vert\vert L_\text{post}^{-1}\hat b_{\eta y}\vert\vert

sec.p: This means that to calculate this density, we must first compute L_\text{post}Lpost, then compute \vert\vert y\vert \vert||y||, where
This can be efficiently computed using the block-Cholesky methods described in the appendix.
In practice, we are not exactly interested in the marginal posterior, \pi(\tau_\eta \vert \hat \eta)π(τη|η̂). Rather, we want to know the value of
In particular, since \log\pi(\hat \eta \vert \eta, \tau_\eta)logπ(η̂|η,τη) is independent of \tau_\etaτη, this cancels out.
Similarly
The conditional posterior of \eta | \hat\eta, \tau_\etaη|η̂,τη becomes

alternatives.tex-math: \log \pi(\eta \vert \hat \eta, \tau_\eta) - \log \pi(\eta \vert \hat \eta, \tau_\eta^*) = \sum_{i=1}^{3n} L_{[i,i] \text{post}} - \sum_{i=1}^{3n}L_{[i,i] \text{post}}^* - \frac12\left( \vert\vert L_\text{post}^{-1}\hat b_{\eta y}\vert\vert - \vert\vert L_\text{post}^{*-1}\hat b_{\eta y}\vert\vert \right)

sec.p: Alltogether, this leaves us with:

alternatives.tex-math: \begin{aligned} \log \pi(\tau_\eta \vert \hat \eta) - \log \pi(\tau_\eta^* \vert \hat \eta) &= \left( \log\pi(\tau_\eta) - \log\pi(\tau_\eta^*) \right) \\ &+ \frac{n}{2}\sum_{i=1}^3\left( \log \tau_i - \log \tau_i^*\right) \\ &+ \sum_{i=1}^{3n} L_{[i,i] \text{post}} - \sum_{i=1}^{3n}L_{[i,i] \text{post}}^* \\ &- \frac12\left( \vert\vert L_\text{post}^{-1}\hat b_{\eta y}\vert\vert - \vert\vert L_\text{post}^{*-1}\hat b_{\eta y}\vert\vert \right) \end{aligned}

sec.title: Latent Field Sampling
sec.p: The latent field is sampled from the conditional normal distribution
where

alternatives.tex-math: Q_{\text{post}} = Q_{\eta y} + Q_\eta \qquad \text{and} \qquad \mu_{\text{post}} = Q_{\text{post}}^{-1}Q_{\eta y}\hat\eta.

sec.p: The first thing we can do to make these calculations faster is to precompute \hat b_{\eta y} = Q_{\eta y} \hat \etab̂ηy=Qηyη̂ between the Max step and the Smooth step, giving us

alternatives.tex-math: Q_{\text{post}} = Q_{\eta y} + Q_\eta \qquad \text{and} \qquad \mu_{\text{post}} = Q_{\text{post}}^{-1}\hat b_{\eta y}.

sec.p: The most efficient way to sample from this posterior is to calculate the Cholesky decomposition
and using that to solve for \mu_\text{post}μpost in
After that, we sample from the latent field by generating a standard normal random vector z \sim \mathrm N(0, I)z∼N(0,I) and using forward substitution to calculate:

sec.title: Algorithm
sec.p: All in all, this leaves us with the following steps to efficiently draw from the posterior:

list-item.p: Initialize \tau_\etaτη and \etaη to sensible values.
Compute L_\text{post}Lpost using Block-Cholesky algorithm and store it.
Compute yy by solving L_\text{post}y = \hat b_{\eta y}Lposty=b̂ηy and store it.
Compute \mu_\text{post}μpost by solving L_\text{post}^T\mu_\text{post} = yLpostTμpost=y and store it.
Compute \frac12\log\vert Q_\text{post}\vert = \sum_{i=1}^{3n} L_{[i,i] \text{post}}12log|Qpost|=∑i=13nL[i,i]post and store it

sec.p: For each iteration:

list-item.p: Propose \tau_\eta^*τη*
Compute L_\text{post}^*Lpost* using Block-Cholesky algorithm and store it.
Compute y^*y* by solving L_\text{post}^*y = \hat b_{\eta y}Lpost*y=b̂ηy and store it.
Compute \frac12\log\vert Q_\text{post}^*\vert = \sum_{i=1}^{3n} L_{[i,i] \text{post}}^*12log|Qpost*|=∑i=13nL[i,i]post* and store it
Compute the log-acceptance ratio \log \pi(\tau_\eta \vert \hat \eta) - \log(\tau_\eta^*\vert \hat \eta)logπ(τη|η̂)−log(τη*|η̂) and accept/reject the proposed \tau_\eta^*τη*
If \tau_\eta^*τη* is accepted:
Set L_\text{post} = L_\text{post}^*Lpost=Lpost*, y = y^*y=y* and \frac12\log\vert Q_\text{post}\vert = \frac12\log\vert Q_\text{post}^*\vert12log|Qpost|=12log|Qpost*|
Compute \mu_\text{post}μpost by solving L_\text{post}^T\mu_\text{post} = yLpostTμpost=y and store it.
Sample from the latent field using the new values of \mu_\text{post}μpost and L_\text{post}Lpost
If \tau_\eta^*τη* is rejected:
Sample from the latent field using the stored values of \mu_\text{post}μpost and L_\text{post}Lpost

sec.title: Computing L_\text{post}Lpost
sec.p: We first write out Q_\text{post}Qpost as

where each block on the diagonal has bandwidth 3 and all the off-diagonal blocks are diagonal matrices. Keep in mind that since the off-diagonal blocks are diagonal matrices we have that Q_{\psi\tau} = Q_{\tau\psi}Qψτ=Qτψ, Q_{\psi\phi} = Q_{\phi\psi}Qψϕ=Qϕψ and Q_{\tau\phi} = Q_{\phi\tau}Qτϕ=Qϕτ. We can thus calculate the Cholesky decomposition
efficiently using a block-Cholesky factorization:

sec.title: Forward Substitution: Solving Ly = bLy=b
sec.p: Partition LL, yy and bb conformably:

alternatives.tex-math: L_\text{post} = \begin{bmatrix} L_{11} & 0 & 0 \\ L_{21} & L_{22} & 0 \\ L_{31} & L_{32} & L_{33}, \end{bmatrix} \qquad y = \begin{bmatrix} y_1 \\ y_2 \\ y_3 \end{bmatrix} \qquad b = \begin{bmatrix} b_1 \\ b_2 \\ b_3 \end{bmatrix}.

sec.p: Partition L^TLT and xx like yy:
Solve for x_3x3
Rearranged:
Solve for x_2x2
Rearranged:

sec.title: Summary of Forward-Backward Step
sec.p: First solve Ly = bLy=b:
Then solve L^Tx = yLTx=y
